 Dono

Throughout history, self-conscious, centrally imposed attempts to "change the world" have ended in disaster and failure. These attempts have always been based on blinkered political ideologies which are top-down theories; they start with the proposed utopia and then come up with ways to reach it.
 
 Examples would be Facist Germany, Communist Russia, Neoconservative US. You cannot implement change by forcing upon people a hypothesis formulated by a bunch of divorced-from-reality intellectuals sitting around and idealising.
 
 Real change has only, historically, come from revolutionary movements which come from within, and from below, and are essentially unpredictable and uncontrollable in nature, or from the collapse of a previously stable and dominating system.
 
 "Political scientists" should definitely be listened to in terms of small-scale 'social engineering', but any attempt at this on the large scale is impossible simply because large-scale change requires large-scale movements, which are created by large-scale problems. Most ideologies are unworkable, which is why our flawed Western democracy is the best we, as the most stable countries in the world, can come up with.
Counterexamples would be Gorbachev's Glasnost and Perestroika (sic), presumably.
